ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NUISANCE CAUSED BY BARN SWALLOWS


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for National Development what measures are being taken to deal with the problem posed by barn swallows in Bukit Batok neighbourhoods 2 and 3, where the droppings from the birds are causing great inconvenience to the residents.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, barn swallows are migratory birds from the Northern Hemisphere. They fly here in September and leave the following year around March. They form communal roost at ledges and gable ends of some apartment blocks in Bukit Batok, Jurong West and Hougang. This phenomenon has come about only in the last couple of years.

    The Primary Production Department, together with the National University of Singapore, the Parks and Recreation Department, the Environment Ministry and the HDB are looking into how to deal with the nuisance caused by these birds. Various measures such as the use of "distress calls" will be tried out to gauge their effectiveness.

HDB ESTATE MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS
(Payment of dues)


    2. Mr Loh Meng See asked the Minister for National Development, with the restructuring and relocation of the Housing and Development Board Area offices, whether arrangements can be made for the elderly to pay their HDB rental/conservancy charges without having to incur additional transport expenses.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, the streamlining of HDB's estate management functions has not affected the arrangements for the collection of rent, loan instalment and service and conservancy charges. Residents can still make payments for current month dues at any HDB branch or

Column: 578

area office. Residents can, in fact, save time and transport cost if they opt to pay through inter-bank GIRO. I encourage all residents, in particular the elderly, to take advantage of the GIRO facility for making payments to the HDB.

PRE-UNIVERSITY COURSES
(Phasing out)


    3. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Education whether the three-year pre-university courses in pre-university centres and schools are achieving their aims.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the 3-year pre-university course was introduced in 1979 to provide an extra year for non-English medium students to upgrade their proficiency in the English language as well as to offer a longer period of learning for the less able students.

    As all schools now use English as the medium of instruction for most of the school subjects, the objective of helping non-English medium students to upgrade their proficiency in the English language is no longer relevant.

    As to the second objective, it is pertinent to note that about 19% of the students in the pre-university classes leave the programme before sitting the GCE 'A' level examination each year. Another 45% fail to obtain a full 'A' level certificate, namely, 2As and 2AO levels including General Paper. Only 16% succeed in gaining admission to NUS or NTI.

    The Ministry intends to phase out the pre-university classes in the secondary schools and to replace them by four post-secondary institutes which will teach a range of commercial and academic subjects. The post-secondary institutes will complement the junior colleges, VITB institutes and polytechnics. Together they will produce the trained manpower, particularly technicians and commercial staff, which our country needs. They will also give every child the opportunity to be educated and trained in marketable skills up to the age of 18.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Batok): Sir, could I ask the Minister to clarify whether the facilities and staff complement in the post-secondary institutes will be as good as the junior colleges?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: The details of the post-secondary institutes are still being worked out. The staff complement will be better than in the present pre-university centres.

ADMISSION CRITERIA FOR JUNIOR COLLEGES


    4. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Education whether the admission criteria for junior colleges have been set too high; and whether many good students have been kept out of junior colleges.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the revised admission criteria for junior colleges were worked out after discussions with principals of secondary schools and junior colleges. In arriving at the criteria, my Ministry took into consideration that the junior college course is essentially an academic course, preparing students for university education. And only academically-inclined students with a broad-based education at 'O' level will derive the most benefit from the course.

    Based on the revised admission criteria, nearly 14,000 students who sat the GCE 'O' level examination in 1988 qualify for admission to the junior colleges. I would like to assure the Member for Bukit Batok that students who can best benefit from a junior college education will not be kept out of the colleges because of the revised admission criteria.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, we heard from one of our Members today that one group, particularly the Malays, have been disadvantaged by this new criteria. Could the Minister clarify on this? Also, whether sufficient time was given in the last few years for students to know the new criteria to make the necessary adjustment to meet with this new criteria.

Column: 580



     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the students were given sufficient time, two years' notice, ie, when they got into Secondary 3, of these changes in the admission criteria so that they could prepare themselves in Secondary 3 and Secondary 4 to do their 'O' levels and make their subject choices to meet the new criteria.

    As to the question of whether any particular group is disadvantaged, I do not think it is accurate to say that any particular group has become disadvantaged. The criteria are explicit and applicable to all groups. The objective is the important thing. The objective is to make sure that the students who come into junior college to prepare for the 'A' levels and to prepare for the possible admission to the university should be academically inclined. And one way in which this can be assured is that they should have a broad enough base of 'O' level subjects for admission to junior colleges.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam): Sir, does it mean that the Minister is desirous of getting more students to get into our polytechnics? Will the polytechnics' admission criteria take into account the students with 'O' level qualifications as against some with 'A' level qualifications who are also getting into the polytechnics.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, we have said on many occasions that students who are at the fringe of the criteria for admission to junior college, ie, those who can just make it into the junior college, should ask themselves whether they should pursue a junior college course which, having got 'A' levels in two years, may or may not be adequate for admission to university. Or instead should they not take an alternative route, ie, go to the polytechnics, do a professional course in three years and come out with a professional diploma which is well accepted by employers. I think under the old criteria, this was true. Under the new criteria, the same consideration applies and students still have to ask themselves the question whether they should go into the junior college or into the polytechnics.

WORK PERMIT HOLDERS MARRYING SINGAPOREANS
(Figures)


    5. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Labour how many male and female work permit holders applied to contract marriage with Singaporeans in 1987 and 1988, and how many applications have been approved.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1987, there were 1,957 applications from work permit holders to marry Singaporeans. 481 of the applicants were males and 1,476 were females. 1,338 applications were approved, comprising 312 males and 1,026 females.

    In 1988, there were 1,882 applications. 439 of the applicants were males and 1,443 were females; 1,204 applications were approved, comprising 285 males and 919 females.

EMPLOYMENT SERVICE DEPARTMENT
(Usefulness)


    6. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Labour how many people are listed in the Employment Service Department for job offers as at the latest convenient date; and whether the Department is still serving a useful purpose in view of the current good job market.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there were 3,379 job-seekers registered with the Employment Service Department (ESD) on 19th February this year.

    With the present good economic conditions, most job seekers would not need much help to find employment. My Ministry has therefore retained only a core staff in the ESD.

    Even in good times, however, there are still some workers who need assistance to find jobs. These are mainly the unskilled and older workers. Many Members of Parliament have also come across constituents who have some difficulty getting a job and have found the ESD a useful avenue for assistance.

Column: 582



    If the expertise of the ESD is to be available to help the unemployed during a recession, it must continue this service, but at a reduced level, during economic booms.

COMMUNITY HOSPITALS


    7. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Health whether there are plans to set up more community hospitals in future; and, if so, where.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the first community hospital to be built in Ang Mo Kio is expected to be completed in 1991. This will be a pilot project to test community acceptance of this new concept in health care. It will also allow the Ministry to identify the type of services that need to be provided in a community hospital.

    If this pilot project is successful, my Ministry will consider building more community hospitals. We have not determined the number nor the location of future community hospitals.

Column: 582

CHILD PSYCHIATRIC CLINIC


    8. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Health (a) if he will give the number of children treated at the child psychiatric clinic as at the latest convenient date; and (b) whether there are plans to strengthen the present services.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, a total of 1,595 children were treated at the Child Psychiatric Clinic in 1988.

    In addition to the Child Psychiatric Clinic at the Institute of Health, child psychiatric sessions were started at the newly-opened Jurong Polyclinic in October 1988.

    We will extend the child psychiatric sessions to other new polyclinics that will be built in Tampines and Yishun in 1990 and 1991, respectively. The services are also being expanded to include older children between the ages of 13 and 20 years. To cope with the increased workload, we will increase the staffing strength over the next three years with the addition of three specialists, a Psychologist and a Medical Social Worker.

    Head V -

     Mr Bernard Chen (Pasir Panjang GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the Finance Minister in his budget speech this year stated that Singapore is likely to have lower economic growth in the longer term because of constraints of various resources. The long-term economic growth at a lower rate depends very much on how the allocation of the scarce resources can be made to the various sectors.

    The nature of the Singapore economy has been one of diversification. This was the result of economic strategy programme which was launched in the early 1970's. The major sectors involved were manufacturing, commerce, which includes tourism, transport and communications, finance and business and construction. The intention of this diversification was to minimize the fluctuations that could come about when one sector grew faster than the others. There was hope at that time that with a well diversified economy we could still continue to grow despite ups and downs.

    The years of high growth following this programme came to an end in 1985 when all the sectors declined at the same time. One of the primary causes for the major downturn was because of the loss of competitiveness of our industries of which the main cause was high cost caused by high wages and at the same time labour shortage, which in turn forced up wages beyond acceptable levels. The Government through the Economic Committee implemented measures which to a large extent corrected these problems and our

Column: 584

competitiveness was restored and remained quite stable for the last few years. Since then, however, with higher growth achieved in the last two years there are signs that the competitiveness may be eroded once again especially with the withdrawal of some concessions introduced during 1985 and the introduction of some new measures which to a large extent affect labour. This has been accentuated by a severe shortage of labour in all sectors.

    Sir, when we want to target lower economic growth rate in a free economy like Singapore, we can face several problems. First, who is to say who should grow faster or who can grow slower? In the private sector, everyone wants to grow faster than the others, implying that if you grow fast enough you make more money. How can we allocate labour to the various sectors? The allocation involves not only foreign labour but also local labour as well. Secondly, in the scramble for these workers, wages will be driven up beyond desired levels. With the levies and statutory contributions imposed on labour usage, the wages may be driven even higher. Thirdly, the cost increases as a result of this increased cost of operations will be reflected, firstly, in reducing our competitiveness in both local and export markets, and indirectly the increasing cost of goods and services will be passed on to the consumers which, of course, then will have an impact on inflation.

    I realize it is a difficult problem when we come to the allocation of labour. It is not easy to play God as to say who should get more than the others. I think the issue facing us at the moment is really how do we find a way to prioritize the various demands on labour, and hopefully at the same time achieve a limit on the use of foreign labour. We recognize the diverse impact posed by too many, foreign labour. The question is, what is too many or how much is too many? We may also have to look seriously into how to induce the underemployed members of the workforce, in particular females, and put their services into the main labour force. In particular, we should also look at how best we can improve the dialogue between the Government and the various industries

Column: 585

and service sectors which have a peculiar demand for labour. Because not everybody in the private sector uses labour the same way. There are certain constraints and there are other ways of making ends meet. In short, I would like to stress that the labour shortage problem and its consequential higher cost is a major problem that we will have to face in the coming years.

    There is also a problem related to the public sector. The public sector, just like the private sector, have the same demand on labour resources as well as other resources like land, utilities and the competition for these resources will be yet another challenge for us. While generally speaking, in the private sector there is a discipline in maximizing the use of these resources because excessive use of these resources will impact on the cost and profits. One wonders whether the same discipline applies to the public sector where the method of accounting and accountability is quite different from the private sector. The question to pose is whether the public sector is also playing a part in ensuring that these resources are maximally utilized. One recent example is the wage increases proposed for civil servants. While we have no objections - in fact, we support increases for wages for civil servants - we cannot ignore the effect that it may have on the private sector and on the economy as a whole. In order to go after the same scarce resources the private sector will have no choice but to respond by way of increasing wages to match those in the public sector. Again, it is a difficult issue. Perhaps one answer to this would be for the Government and the public sector as a whole to increasingly switch its remuneration system to one of performance related, as in the private sector. In this case there will not be a substantial across the board increase which will drive up wages in all sectors of the economy, rather the better performers will get better rewards as should be the case. And if the private sector were to go after the same resource, then they have to pay for it. But the overall wage level can be maintained at tolerable levels.

Column: 586



    Sir, I myself for that matter have not got a real solution to this labour problem. All I can suggest to the Minister is perhaps, being in charge of the economy of Singapore, he can find some ways and means of making the ends meet. In other words, try to have the cake and eat it at the same time. But I think seriously it is a problem that we all face and I hope that the Ministry will allocate some priority in examining the solutions possible.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Mr Chairman, Sir, as the Ministry that is in charge of Singapore's economic development, MTI acts as a macro economic planner by setting broad policy objectives to ensure that our economy continues to grow.

    Ever since the recession of 1985, fears have been expressed by business on almost all Government policies that have fiscal implications. In general, businesses are apprehensive of those policies that have an impact on their cost of doing business. To go one step further, it may be argued that policies relating to the use of land, the mode and control of land transport, and of course, the control of foreign workers and foreign maids have both social and economic implications-not only on businesses but the population at large. In the case of land transport and housing, due to our limited land resources, what we do today will have economic and other implications for the next generation of Singaporeans. On a specific policy like the foreign workers' levy, no distinction or differentiation is made on the impact on different industries and different kind of enterprises. For instance, local companies which are significantly export-oriented are no more favoured than one which produces for the local market. Bearing in mind that market share and trade channels take considerable time to develop, a blanket policy like the foreign workers' levy may easily damage such a local enterprise. This is an undesirable consequence as we are seeking to help some local companies grow into multi-nationals.

    Sir, for the reasons and examples which I have mentioned, MTI must play a wider role and coordinate at the micro level in more detail and, if not, to go to the extent

Column: 587

of scrutinizing the policies of other Government ministries so that the wider economic implications are taken into consideration. The Minister will have my support if MTI's role is expanded in this direction.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Mr Chairman, Sir, the Government has projected a long term moderate economic growth of 4-6% a year. Sir, this is a realistic target given the constraints to our growth posed by the shortage of land and manpower resources. Sir, if we can achieve this economic growth rate, we could continue to live comfortably with improvement in the standard of living and our quality of life.

    But, Sir, should we be contented with this moderate growth rates? I think we can do better. Our economy has the inherent potential to grow much faster. I am not advocating that we open the gate for a large influx of foreign workers. What I have in mind, Sir, is that we as a country, both the private and the public sectors, have large financial resources. We should harness these resources to achieve higher growth, invest these resources overseas in markets where there are no constraints on land and manpower.

    Sir, we have a number of home grown Singapore companies. Most of them are cash rich with the financial muscles to venture abroad, invest in markets overseas and remit profits back to Singapore. Many have the potential to be large MNCs or the so-called "Singapore Inc." Sir, this idea of forming Singapore Inc. was mooted more than 10 years ago but we have not consciously promote it. I think it is timely now to pursue this idea more vigorously.

    Sir, we are embarking on the next phase of our economic development where we should measure our national income more in terms of GNP rather than GDP. I think in time to come income generated from overseas will form a sizeable part of our economic pie. The Government should take the lead to develop Singapore MNCs. I know MTI has started this by getting the EDB and the TDB to help local companies look

Column: 588

for investment opportunities abroad but these efforts alone are not enough. The Government should also consider being a financial partner in some of these ventures. Incentives must be introduced to encourage Singaporeans to accept overseas postings. There must be a conscious and coordinated effort by the Government to channel resources towards grooming Singapore MNCs.

    May I conclude by urging the Minister to seriously look at these suggestions. Our economy has the potential to grow faster. Let us not be contented with 4-6% growth.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee): Sir, last year, our economic growth rate was 11%, out of which 2.8% was attributed to foreign labour. In other words, without foreign workers, we could not have achieved such a high growth rate. However, the inflow of foreign workers has a high social cost. So two questions come to mind: (1) Are we prepared to live with a slower economic growth so as to avoid the social cost? Or are we prepared to press on with more rapid economic growth and live with a higher social cost? There is a trade-off between economic and social objectives. (2) Are there constraints to our long term economic growth?

    Sir, our land area is fixed and our local supply of labour could only increase slowly. These problems are different from the problems of small domestic market size. Small domestic market size imposes limits on the demand side. Scarce resources impose limits from the supply side. We have overcome the demand side limits by exporting our goods and services to the world. The world is our market. Do we have similar long term solutions to the supply-side constraints as imposed by our scarce resources? To some extent, these resource constraints could be overcome by making more intensive use and more efficient use of these resources, but there are problems in these areas also. For example, if we increase the female labour force participation rate, we will also incur social cost. Another example is if we make more intensive use of our land, it will mean higher intensity and lowering of our living standard. One solution could be to

Column: 589

build up or promote our local MNCs, as suggested by Mr Chew Heng Ching and a few days ago, by Dr Hong Hai.

    Sir, another issue I would like to raise is the question of "externalities". It is a highly technical subject and normally I spend one hour lecture to elaborate on this subject. But here because of time constraints, I will simply put it this way. Externalities refer to the external effects generated by an economic activity or policy on other economic agents but for which no price is paid. A classical example is pollution. But let me relate externality concepts to land and labour. The inflow of foreign workers has generated negative external effects, but employers of foreign workers would not have taken these social costs into account, if not for the foreign workers levy. Foreign workers levy therefore is not just a measure to regulate the inflow of foreign workers, the foreign workers levy could also be regarded as a measure to make these employers to internalize the negative externality.

    However, externalities could be positive or beneficial. For example, when Government develops an efficient economic infrastructure, it benefits the whole economy in general, and increases land value in particular. To the extent that beneficial externalities are not taken into account, say, in the construction of Government offices, hospitals, schools, expressways or MRT lines, there would be hidden costs and the subsidies to these projects would be understated. Failure to internalize externalities, either positive or negative externalities, could lead to distortions in our price system, and worse, misallocation of scarce resources.

    Hence, there should be a more realistic assessment of any policy proposal in terms of its social and economic benefits and social and economic costs. Furthermore, I agree with Mr Chng Hee Kok that there should also be a better coordination and regular review of policy measures which have claims on our scarce resources - land and labour. We must bear in mind that at any given time, the supplies of these scarce resources are fixed. Any increase in the demand for these scarce resources by the public sector would

Column: 590

necessarily be at the expense of the private sector.

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Sir, the mission statement of the Ministry of Trade and Industry is to maintain economic stability in the country and to promote Singapore's economic growth. I wish to congratulate the Ministry for having done an excellent job and bringing about an economic growth rate of 8.8% in 1987 and 11% in 1988.

    Like my colleagues before me, I note with concern, however, that out of this 11% economic growth, 2.8% of this growth was contributed by foreign labour. To maintain strong economic growth with too much reliance on foreign labour is not sustainable in the long term, as many have pointed out. Too much reliance on foreign labour also artificially depresses our workers' wages and creates social and political problems. Therefore, in this respect, I am pleased to note that the Government has taken action to contain the problem in two ways. Firstly, by increasing the foreign workers levy and, secondly, reducing the ratio of foreign workers to total workforce from 50% to 40%. Hopefully, this will encourage employers to robotize, automate and computerize their operations and also employ retirees, housewives and the physically handicapped first before resorting to employing foreign labour.

    Despite the labour shortage, the EDB is still working very hard to attract foreign investments to Singapore. In view of our labour shortage problem, I would like to ask the Minister whether EDB is now more selective in the types of industries we are trying to attract and, if so, what are some of these industries? New industries will also mean greater demand for certain types of skilled manpower resources. In order not to be too dependent on foreign skilled resources in this area, how does the Ministry plan and coordinate the training of such skilled manpower at all levels for these industries which EDB is trying to attract?

    In the last recession when shipbuilding and ship repair was badly affected, many workers were retrenched - skilled labour, technicians and marine engineers alike.

Column: 591

The polytechnics, however, were still training such skilled technicians in the midst of the economic downturn. When they graduated, many ended up in jobs totally unrelated to their area of training. This seems to be a waste of training resources. Recently, the ship-repair business has picked up. However, I am given to understand that many students in the polytechnics are still avoiding the shipbuilding and offshore engineering department. This may lead to a shortage of such skilled labour in the ship-repair industry later. I hope the Ministry will look into matching the training of our limited manpower resources to the needs of industry and the services which we provide so that our economic stability can be maintained in the long term.

     The Chairman: I would like to inform Members that the time allotted for this amendment is 38 minutes, and not 75 minutes as announced earlier. General Lee.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Sir, I intend to present a general reply to the points which have been raised by the speakers so far. I will leave it to my Minister of State and Senior Parliamentary Secretary to deal with the details later. Mr Bernard Chen and the others have raised two major issues.     The Member for Leng Kee just now gave an example of an externality. It is a big word, but the idea is simple. If you pollute the environment, you do not pay the cost but all your neighours pay the cost, because they suffer your black smoke. That is an externality: you are doing it to them. If you drive into a traffic jam, your own journey takes five minutes longer, but because you have contributed to the traffic jam, everybody else's journey also takes five minutes longer. You have imposed total delays on other car drivers a hundred to a thousand times larger than what you yourself suffer - that is an externality. When that happens, we have got some way to fix it.
